description: Practice the meanings and usage of phrasal verbs with 'out' using definition matching questions.

questions.question: find out
questions.answer: To discover information or learn something.
questions.example: I need to find out who owns this car.
choices: To discover information or learn something.

questions.question: run out
questions.answer: To have no more of something left.
questions.example: We ran out of milk this morning.
choices: To have no more of something left.

questions.question: break out
questions.answer: To start suddenly, often used for fights or wars.
questions.example: A fire broke out in the kitchen.
choices: To start suddenly, often used for fights or wars.

questions.question: burn out
questions.answer: To become extremely tired or exhausted from overwork.
questions.example: He burned out after months of overtime.
choices: To become extremely tired or exhausted from overwork.

questions.question: drop out
questions.answer: To leave school or an activity before finishing it.
questions.example: She dropped out of college last year.
choices: To leave school or an activity before finishing it.
To invite someone on a date.

questions.question: come out
questions.answer: To become known or be released.
questions.example: The new book comes out next month.
choices: To become known or be released.

questions.question: turn out
questions.answer: To result or end in a particular way.
questions.example: The party turned out better than we expected.
choices: To result or end in a particular way.

questions.question: fall out
questions.answer: To quarrel or stop being friendly with someone.
questions.example: They fell out over a trivial matter.
choices: To quarrel or stop being friendly with someone.

questions.question: hand out
questions.answer: To distribute something to a group of people.
questions.example: The teacher handed out the tests.
choices: To distribute something to a group of people.
To pick someone up in a car.

questions.question: point out
questions.answer: To draw attention to something or someone.
questions.example: She pointed out the mistake in my essay.
choices: To draw attention to something or someone.
To turn down a job offer.
To make up after a fight.

questions.question: stick out
questions.answer: To be noticeable or easily seen.
questions.example: His bright tie really sticks out.
choices: To be noticeable or easily seen.
To borrow money from a bank.

questions.question: stand out
questions.answer: To be very noticeable or superior to others.
questions.example: Her talent makes her stand out from the rest.
choices: To be very noticeable or superior to others.

questions.question: work out
questions.answer: To exercise or to find a solution to a problem.
questions.example: We finally worked out how to fix the error.
choices: To exercise or to find a solution to a problem.

questions.question: carry out
questions.answer: To complete or perform a task.
questions.example: The scientists carried out several tests.
choices: To complete or perform a task.

questions.question: back out
questions.answer: To decide not to do something previously agreed.
questions.example: He backed out of the deal at the last minute.
choices: To decide not to do something previously agreed.

questions.question: check out
questions.answer: To examine or look at something interesting.
questions.example: You should check out that new caf√© downtown.
choices: To examine or look at something interesting.

questions.question: figure out
questions.answer: To understand or solve something.
questions.example: We need to figure out how this machine works.

questions.question: pass out
questions.answer: To become unconscious or faint.
questions.example: He passed out from the heat.
choices: To meet someone for the first time.

questions.question: single out
questions.answer: To choose one person or thing from a group for special attention.
questions.example: The teacher singled out the best performer.
choices: To choose one person or thing from a group for special attention.
To delay the beginning of something.

questions.question: turn out
questions.answer: To attend or be present at an event.
questions.example: A large crowd turned out for the concert.
choices: To attend or be present at an event.

title: Phrasal Verbs with 'Out'
